newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanese pound firms against dollar.
newsitem.headline: Lebanese pound firms against dollar.

text.p: The Lebanese pound regained ground against the U.S. dollar in quiet interbank trade in Beirut on Monday and dealers said the market was calming down after a flurry of activity last week.

The market opened at 1,546-1,549 pounds to the dollar from 1,548.5 on Friday, but the Lebanese currency firmed steadily during the morning to 1,543-1,545, a dealer who asked not to be identified told Reuters.
The pound moved at the close to 1,545-1,548 per dollar as some banks closed their positions, the dealer added. He estimated trade at $4-$5 million.
The Bank of Lebanon's bid-offer intervention band was unchanged from last week's 1,540-1549.5 pounds per dollar.
"All trade was within the Bank of Lebanon's intervention rate and there was some selling of dollars by banks due to treasury bill purchases and the Eid al-Adha holiday on Thursday," the dealer added.
"I think it is a matter of time before we have a calm market again. There was nothing special today," he said.

Last week the pound fell six points against the dollar within the central bank's intervention band in interbank trade as one commercial bank bought a large amount of the U.S. currency, putting pressure on the Lebanese pound.
